results.title: Bribie
results.creator_credit: Kevin Brady, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Kevin Brady sets the record straight on the Battle of Bribie, considered to be the closest Australia got to losing a battle in Vietnam. His “digger’s account” illustrates the major obstacles and the bravery shown by the men, who were met with gunfire on landing.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kevin Brady, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Becoming an Australian
results.creator_credit: George Logan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: It wasn’t until George Logan served in the army overseas that he felt like a true Australian. Serving as an infantryman in Malaya and Vietnam, it was the values of mateship, care and concern for others that remain with Logan today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Logan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: It wasn’t until George Logan served in the army overseas that he felt like a true Australian. Serving as an infantryman in Malaya and Vietnam, it was the values of mateship, care and concern for others that remain with Logan today.

results.title: Always a survivor
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, David Catterall and ACMI
results.brief_description: When David Catterall returned from the horrors of the Vietnam War, he found his personal and professional life disintergrating. It was then that Catterall discovered the supportive community made up by his fellow returned soldiers and credits them with enabling him to pull through some of the darkest moments of his life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, David Catterall and ACMI

results.title: La Cage (The Cage) thaumatrope
results.brief_description: Not printed - not required - original object = front. Graphic of AEO175943 (front)
results.description: How do you cage a bird? With a thaumatrope, an optical toy that binds a disc to lengths of string. Illustrated on each side of the disc are distinct images that become one when you pull the string and the thaumatrope spins. The first known thaumatrope was invented by John Ayrton Paris in 1824, when he used it to demonstrate his theory of ‘persistence of vision’ to London’s Royal College of Physicians.
description_for_label: How do you cage a bird? With a thaumatrope, an optical toy that binds a disc to lengths of string. Illustrated on each side of the disc are distinct images that become one when you pull the string and the thaumatrope spins. The first known thaumatrope was invented by John Ayrton Paris in 1824, when he used it to demonstrate his theory of ‘persistence of vision’ to London’s Royal College of Physicians.

results.title: Selected works from "Bute utes: the movie"
results.brief_description:
A selection of 9 narrative works from across regional Victoria by various storytellers.
Produced by Regional Arts Victoria, ACE Connections, East Gippsland Aboriginal Arts Corporation, Robinvale Cultural Festival and Network House, The South-West Institute of TAFE and the Tarerer Gunditj Association and supported by The Regional Arts Fund, The Myer Foundation and VicHealth.

results.title: We used to call them Blackboys
results.creator_credit: Goulburn Ovens Institute of TAFE and Maz McGann
results.brief_description: Using photographic images, this story of the grass trees growing on the ranges outside Wangaratta becomes a poetic meditation on how a person’s ideas on place can change with understanding and compassion. European insensitivity and ignorance of the past has been replaced with political awareness and correctness, a sense of the land and the environment and a desire for reconciliation with those who belonged to the land before the invasion of the white man. A sensitive and thought-provoking piece. Made as part of Regional Arts Victoria’s Bute Utes - the Movie program.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Goulburn Ovens Institute of TAFE and Maz McGann
results.description: Using photographic images, this story of the grass trees growing on the ranges outside Wangaratta becomes a poetic meditation on how a person’s ideas on place can change with understanding and compassion. results.title: Road trip: after the Gippsland bushfires 2003
results.brief_description:
A road trip through the East Gippsland region of Victoria after the bushfires in 2003 and a chance meeting at a place called Seldom Seen, somewhere between Jindabyne and Buchan, with David Woodburn owner of the “Seldom Seen Service Statiion”. David talks of his encounter with the fires, his loss of his family home, the service station and many of his pet animals including an emu and an ostrich. But it is David’s eccentricity and sardonic humour, along with the wonderful quirky photographic shots that makes this story so engaging and appealing.
Created as part of the “Bute Utes the Movie” project in association with Regional Arts Victoria.

results.title: Op shops of our town
results.brief_description: An amusing ‘mockumentary’ on several of the Op Shops in the East Gippsland region. This tongue-in-cheek journey introduces us to the eccentricities of op-shopping, the people who run them, the people who shop in them, and the eclectic mix of goods found in them. Stars Mr Kearney and Ms Jennian, with thanks to the following participating Op Shops - Paynesville Op Shop and Uniting Church, Lakes Entrance Ambulance, Salvos and St Vincents in Bairnsdale. Music from the fabulous Stereophonic Optigan, written and played by Mr Kearney. Camera - Jeremy Johnson.

results.title: My grandfather's country
results.creator_credit: Lisa Roberts, Edie Terrick, Poogie Hayes and Elaine Terrick
results.brief_description:
Elaine Terrick’s mum, Edie Terrick, takes a journey back to the place she calls her grandfather’s country - in the mountainous ranges of Gippsland, Victoria. A place where her grandfather survived the slaughtering of his aboriginal people and where he as an abandoned child was found by white people - the O’Rourke family - taken in and brought up as an O’Rourke. For Edie it is an emotional but rewarding journey. Contains beautiful images of the high country and of the “place” where Edi’s grandfather grew up.
Created as part of the “Bute Utes the Movie” project in association with Regional Arts Victoria.

results.title: A Magic place
results.creator_credit: Goulburn Ovens Institute of TAFE, Linton Briggs, Kathy Whelan and David Briggs
results.brief_description:
Narrated to a background of archival home movie images juxtaposed with contemporary images of Lake Mokoan and the surrounding landscape, local resident Linton Briggs gives his account of the changes which have taken place since the decommissioning of the Lake. He speaks of a magic place, Winton Swamp, where wildlife was in abundance, where a wet-land ecosystem of bird-life, Murray cod, Red-gums, and every variety of duck imaginable used to exist and of his sadness and apprehension the changing of the lake may make to the ecological balance of Lake Mokoan.
Created as part of the “Bute Utes the Movie” project in association with Regional Arts Victoria.
